A bit annoyed about this. See this screenshot?

Now compare it to what the docs says it is for and tell me if you notice a distinct gap between what we're telling users and what we're telling developers.

https://docs.joinmastodon.org/spec/activitypub/#discoverable

This is the setting that federates, not the "opt out of search indexing" which is for search engines (like Google) indexing only.

With this setting off or posting Unlisted, none of your posts should be searchable by full-text indexing from other servers, because the current universeodon search patch respects this setting.

The annoying part is that the Mastodon UI makes it sounds like you're opting only into profile discoverability, whereas on the backend it is telling developers to use it as an opt-in for search.

title: The UK’s Secretive Web Surveillance Program Is Ramping Up

last_post.content:
The UK is now building a national system to allow police to access and inspect people's internet history

In 2016, the government passed the Investigatory Powers Act, also known as the Snooper's Charter

The law says telecoms companies can be made to collection people's 'internet connection records' and store them for up to a year

Internet connection records are essentially the websites you visit, but not the individual pages upon them

For the last few months, the UK has been creating a 'national' system that will allow law enforcement to access and 'filter' internet connection records

An initial police trial of the records has found “significant operational benefit”

https://www.wired.com/story/internet-connection-records-uk-surveillance/

#tech #news #privacy #surveillance #infosec

I'm tired of reading about how #Meta manipulates people through AI and algorithms -- and having these manipulations being pitched as "innovations" by tech media.

#Vice Magazine has filed for bankruptcy. This is the end of an era.

If you're between the ages of 30-50, Vice was core to documenting youth culture as you remember it. At least that was the case for me.

Growing up in Canada during the 90s, I remember Vice as a punk rock zine that published things that were completely unprintable everywhere else. It published articles about drugs, sex, fashion, rock n' roll -- everything I was into.

As time went on, Vice became tamer and tamer until it became the antithesis of what it once was. Towards the latter end of its existence, Vice was pretty much a Buzzfeed competitor.

Nevertheless, with the benefit of hindsight, I now see Vice for what it is: crass hipsterdom gone amuck, opportunists to the core.

I will miss Vice as a journal for millennial youth culture. I won't miss the exploitation of all the writers who made it what it was.

https://www.bbc.com/news/business-65462957

Insider reviewed #Lemon8, Bytedance's #Instagram/#Pinterest clone. In case you're wondering, Bytedance is the company behind #TikTok.

Months ago, I looked through Lemon8's site, fooled around, and came to the same conclusion as the reviewer. But I'm also nowhere near Bytedance's targeted demographic for this, so reading from someone who is bring clarity.

That said, I am a big fan of the Instagram and Pinterest experience, but those apps have been enshittified long ago, and I've been hoping for good Fediverse contenders for awhile. This is why I can continue to run my #Pixelfed server since this is such a critical app.

I hope can all collectively build something more compelling than Lemon8.

I agree with @jwildeboer@social.wildeboer.net about how DMs shouldn't be sent unless a relationship of trust (perhaps by mutual follows) gets established first.

However, maybe it's time to retire DMs -- at least as implemented on Mastodon.

Even with recent UI changes, they're easy to confuse for regular messages -- making it all too easy to make a faux pas with visibility settings.

Now some server software (like #Calckey and #Pleroma) have a chat system with a UI that makes it clear that the discussion is not to be confused with status updates. Moreover, these are not Mastodon-style DMs either, but something separate.

I personally prefer chat over DMs. And while I think there's lots of room to improve them, chats are an upgraded user experience over DMs.

Based on a discussion that I've had with @Gargron@mastodon.social, I don't think he likes DMs either. I remember him talking about building a separate chat system. That's probably not a bad idea.

I understand where @AbandonedAmerica@mastodon.social is coming from, and it's something I heavily struggled with before migrating from mastodon.social to calckey.social.

So I mean this from the bottom of my heart: we should not be defederating mastodon.social.

In fact, we should stop using Fediblock as the answer to all the Fediverse's problems. Been there, done that. Not something I want to do again.

Instead, we need to make it as easy as possible for people on mastodon.social to migrate elsewhere should they choose.

We should make the penalties from migrating be as trivial as possible. This is one reason #Calckey isn't just allowing users to migrate to a Calckey server from a #Mastodon server, but also why importing posts from a Mastodon account to Calckey is so critical too.

In other words, let's help people leave mastodon.social when they're ready to make the decision to leave.
